total_revenue.context: Total revenue for Q2, up 40% year-on-year.

segments.name: Gaming

revenue.context: Gaming segment revenue for Q2, up 52% year-on-year and 5% sequentially.

key_points: Growth driven by desktop, notebook, and gaming consoles, all up strong double-digit percentages year-on-year.
Max-Q technology enabled slim gaming notebooks, with 26 models expected in stores for the holidays.
eSports audience reached 400 million, up 18% year-on-year.
Partnerships with EA for Battlefield 5 and Square Enix for Shadow of the Tomb Raider.
Launch of Turing architecture with RT Cores and Tensor Cores for real-time ray-tracing and AI inferencing.

segments.name: Datacenter

revenue.context: Datacenter segment revenue for Q2, up 83% year-on-year and 8% sequentially.

key_points: Driven by hyperscale demand and adoption of AI and high-performance computing solutions.
Launch of TensorRT 4 AI inference accelerator software, delivering up to 190x performance speed-up relative to CPUs.
Annual run rate for DGX AI server in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
Partnerships with NetApp and Pure Storage for AI deployment.
NVIDIA GPUs power five of the world's seven fastest supercomputers.

segments.name: Pro Visualization

revenue.context: Pro Visualization segment revenue for Q2, up 20% year-on-year and 12% sequentially.

key_points: Driven by demand for real-time rendering, mobile workstations, and emerging applications like AI and VR.
Emerging applications represent approximately 35% of Pro Visualization sales.
Launch of Turing-based Quadro RTX GPUs for interactive ray-tracing.

segments.name: Automotive

revenue.context: Automotive segment revenue for Q2, up 13% year-on-year and 11% sequentially.

key_points: Growth driven by autonomous vehicle production and AI-based smart cockpit infotainment solutions.
Partnership with Daimler and Bosch for level 4 and level 5 autonomous fleets.
Launch of DRIVE Pegasus AI supercomputer for autonomous vehicles.

segments.name: Tegra Processor

revenue.context: Tegra Processor segment revenue for Q2, up 40% year-on-year.

key_points: Revenue grew 40% to $467 million, driven by increased demand in automotive and mobile markets.

segments.name: GPU

revenue.context: GPU segment revenue for Q2, up 40% year-on-year.

key_points: GPU revenue grew 40% year-on-year to $2.66 billion.
Strong sales of Turing-based RTX GPUs driving growth.
High-end and midrange GPU sales rebounded post-cryptocurrency decline.

net_income.context: GAAP net income for Q2, up 89% year-on-year.

non_gaap_net_income.context: Non-GAAP net income for Q2, up 90% year-on-year.

non_gaap_eps.context: Non-GAAP EPS for Q2, up 92% year-on-year.

revenue.context: Revenue guidance for Q3 FY2019, plus or minus 2%.

gross_margin.context: GAAP gross margin guidance for Q3 FY2019, plus or minus 50 basis points.

capital_expenditures.context: Capital expenditures guidance for Q3 FY2019.

strategic_initiatives: Expansion of TensorRT AI inference accelerator software to address broader deep learning workloads.
Partnerships with NetApp and Pure Storage for AI deployment.
Launch of DRIVE Pegasus AI supercomputer for autonomous vehicles.
Partnerships with EA, Square Enix, and other gaming developers for new game releases.
Launch of Turing architecture with RT Cores and Tensor Cores for real-time ray-tracing and AI inferencing.

market_opportunities.Gaming: Expanding eSports audience and new game releases driving demand for GPUs.

market_opportunities.Datacenter: Growing adoption of AI and high-performance computing solutions across industries.

market_opportunities.Pro Visualization: Emerging applications like AI and VR driving demand for real-time rendering and mobile workstations.

market_opportunities.Automotive: Increasing adoption of AI-based autonomous vehicle and smart cockpit solutions.

introduction: Q2 revenue reached $3.12 billion, up 40% from a year earlier.
All market platforms—Gaming, Datacenter, Pro Visualization, and Automotive—grew double digits both sequentially and year-on-year.
Crypto-specific product revenue declined sharply, contributing negligibly to the current quarter.
gaming: Gaming revenue of $1.8 billion was up 52% year-on-year and up 5% sequentially.
Growth driven by all segments of the business with desktop, notebook, and gaming consoles up strong double-digit percentages year-on-year.
Notebooks were a standout this quarter with strong demand for thin and light form factors based on our Max-Q technology.
Max-Q enables gaming PC OEMs to pack a high-performance GPU into a slim notebook that is just 20 millimeters thick or less.
Expect to see 26 Max-Q models in stores for the holidays.
eSports audience reached 400 million, up 18% year-on-year.
Partnerships with EA for Battlefield 5 and Square Enix for Shadow of the Tomb Raider.
Launch of Turing architecture with RT Cores and Tensor Cores for real-time ray-tracing and AI inferencing, delivering up to 2x the performance of Pascal and 6x more for ray-traced graphics.
First two GeForce RTX gaming cards, the 2080 Ti and the 2080, delivered 4K HDR gaming and 60 FPS on advanced AAA titles.
Pipeline of upcoming games supporting NVIDIA RTX features is well on its way to establishing RTX as a game-changing architecture.
Post-crypto channel inventory took longer than expected to normalize, leading to weaker-than-expected sales of midrange Pascal gaming cards.
Pascal positioned as the GPU of choice in the midrange for the holidays; expect to work down channel inventories over the next quarter or two.
datacenter: Datacenter revenue was $0.76 billion, up 83% year-on-year and up 8% sequentially.
Strong demand driven by hyperscale adoption and AI/high-performance computing solutions.
Launch of TensorRT 4 AI inference accelerator software, delivering up to 190x performance speed-up relative to CPUs.
Annual run rate for DGX AI server in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
Partnerships with NetApp and Pure Storage to accelerate AI deployment.
NVIDIA GPUs power five of the world's seven fastest supercomputers.
Launch of DRIVE Pegasus AI supercomputer for autonomous vehicles, delivering 320 trillion operations per second.
Introduction of RAPIDS, a GPU-accelerated data analytics and machine learning platform, opening up a $20 billion server market.
Strong industry support from developers like Adobe, ANSYS, Autodesk, Dassault, and others.
Increase in TOP500 supercomputer systems using NVIDIA GPUs by 48% from last year, including the #1 and #2 systems.
pro_vis: Professional Visualization revenue reached $0.281 billion, up 20% year-on-year and up 12% sequentially.
Driven by demand for real-time rendering, mobile workstations, and emerging applications like AI and VR.
Emerging applications now represent approximately 35% of Pro Visualization sales.
Launch of Turing-based Quadro RTX GPUs for interactive ray-tracing.
Strength extended across several key industries including healthcare, oil and gas, and media and entertainment.
Key wins include Raytheon, Lockheed, GE, Siemens, and Phillips Healthcare.
Launch of Quadro RTX 8000, 6000, and 5000 GPUs based on Turing architecture.
Introduction of Quadro RTX 4000, the most advanced professional GPU priced under $1,000.
RTX Ray tracing transforming the visual effects industry, enabling researchers and developers to achieve photorealistic rendering, augmented reality, and virtual reality.
automotive: Automotive revenue was $0.161 billion, up 13% year-on-year and up 11% sequentially.
Growth driven by autonomous vehicle production and AI-based smart cockpit infotainment solutions.
Partnership with Daimler and Bosch for level 4 and level 5 autonomous fleets.
Launch of DRIVE Pegasus AI supercomputer for autonomous vehicles, delivering 320 trillion operations per second.
Development kit for DRIVE Pegasus AI supercomputer started shipping in Q2.
Introduced DRIVE Pegasus AI supercomputer, designed specifically for autonomous vehicles, with enhanced performance and safety features.
Positions NVIDIA in a $30 billion addressable market for autonomous vehicles by 2025, offering an end-to-end platform from AI computing infrastructure to simulation and in-car computing.
financials: Q2 GAAP gross margin was 63.3%, and non-GAAP gross margin was 63.5%, in line with our outlook.
GAAP operating expenses were $818 million, and non-GAAP operating expenses were $692 million, up 30% year-on-year.
Continues to invest in the key platforms driving long-term growth including Gaming, AI, and Automotive.
GAAP net income was $1.1 billion, up 89% year-on-year.
Non-GAAP net income was $1.21 billion, up 90% year-on-year.
Quarterly cash flow from operations was $0.913 billion.
Returned $1.95 billion to shareholders in fiscal year 2019 through a combination of quarterly dividends and share repurchases.
Announced a $0.01 increase in our quarterly dividend to $0.16 effective in Q4 of fiscal 2019.
Increased share repurchase authorization by $7 billion and intend to return an additional $3 billion to shareholders by the end of fiscal 2020.
q3_outlook: Expect revenue for Q3 FY2019 to be $3.25 billion, plus or minus 2%.
GAAP gross margin expected to be 62.6% ±50 basis points.
Non-GAAP gross margin expected to be 62.8% ±50 basis points.
Capital expenditures expected to be approximately $0.125 billion.
Assumes normalization of channel inventory and seasonal trends to support revenue outlook.
investor_relations: Posted an investor presentation summarizing Q2 results and key highlights.
Committed to returning $3 billion to shareholders through dividends and buybacks by the end of fiscal 2020.
Upcoming events: Morgan Stanley Technology, Media and Telecom Conference on February 26; RBC Future of Mobility Conference on June 6; and NASDAQ Investor Conference on June 13.
